Yet, generally I do not think that in the context of the search for the NSM (see Goal 20) it is a good strategy to project the results of all future measurements of rare decays on the (ϱˉ,ηˉ)(\bar\varrho,\bar\eta)(ϱˉ​,ηˉ​) plane or any other of five planes related to the remaining unitarity triangles. This would only teach us about possible inconsistences within the SM but would not point towards a particular NP model.

In view of this, here comes a proposal for the strategy for searching for NP in the next decade, in which hopefully RbR_bRb​ and γ\gammaγ will be precisely measured, CP violation in the BsB_sBs​ system explored and many goals listed in the previous section reached.

This strategy, which is a summary of many ideas present already in the literature, proceeds in three steps:

Step 1

In order to study transparently possible tensions between εK\varepsilon_KεK​, sin⁡2β\sin 2\betasin2β, ∣Vub∣\vub∣Vub​∣, γ\gammaγ and RtR_tRt​ let us leave the (ϱˉ,ηˉ)(\bar\varrho,\bar\eta)(ϱˉ​,ηˉ​) plane and {go to} the Rb−γR_b-\gammaRb​−γ plane 250 suggested already several years ago and recently strongly supported by the analyses in 25155. The Rb−γR_b-\gammaRb​−γ plane is shown in Fig.~Fig. 4. We will explain this figure in the next subsection.

Step 2

In order to search for NP in rare KKK, BdB_dBd​, BsB_sBs​, DDD decays, in CP violation in BsB_sBs​ and charm decays, in LFV decays, in EDM's and (g−2)μ(g-2)_\mu(g−2)μ​ let us go to specific plots that exhibit correlations between various observables. As we will see below such correlations will be crucial to distinguish various NP scenarios. Of particular importance are the correlations between the CP asymmetry SψϕS_{\psi\phi}Sψϕ​ and Bs→μ+μ−B_s\rightarrow\mu^+\mu^-Bs​→μ+μ−, between the anomalies in SϕKsS_{\phi K_s}SϕKs​​ and SψϕS_{\psi\phi}Sψϕ​, between K+→π+ννˉ\kpnK+→π+ννˉ and KL→π0ννˉ\klpnKL​→π0ννˉ, between K+→π+ννˉ\kpnK+→π+ννˉ and SψϕS_{\psi\phi}Sψϕ​, between SϕKsS_{\phi K_s}SϕKs​​ and ded_ede​, between SψϕS_{\psi\phi}Sψϕ​ and (g−2)μ(g-2)_{\mu}(g−2)μ​ and also those involving lepton flavour violating decays.

Step 3

In order to monitor the progress made in the next decade when additional data on flavour changing processes will become available, it is useful to construct a ``DNA-Flavour Test'' of NP models 55 including Supersymmetry, the LHT model, the RSc and various supersymmetric flavour models and other models, with the aim to distinguish between these NP scenarios in a global manner.

Having this strategy in mind we will in the rest of this writing illustrate it on several examples.

The \mathbf{\varepsilon_K-Anomaly and Related Tensions} The CP-violating parameter εK\varepsilon_KεK​ in the SM is given as follows \be |\varepsilon_K|^SM=\kappa_\varepsilon C_\varepsilon\hat B_K\vcb^2\vus^2 \left(\frac{1}{2}\vcb^2R_t^2\sin 2\beta\eta_{tt}S_0(x_t)+ R_t\sin\beta(\eta_{ct}S_0(x_c,x_t)-\eta_{cc}x_c)\right), \ee where CεC_\varepsilonCε​ is a numerical constant and the SM loop functions S0S_0S0​ depend on xi=mi2(mi)/MW2x_i= m_i^2(m_i)/M_W^2xi​=mi2​(mi​)/MW2​. The factors ηij\eta_{ij}ηij​ are QCD corrections known at the NLO level 252253254255, B^K\hat B_KB^K​ is a non-perturbative parameter and κε\kappa_\varepsilonκε​ is explained below.

Until the discovery of CP violation in the BdB_dBd​ system, εK\varepsilon_KεK​ played the crucial role in tests of CP violation, but after the precise measurements of sin⁡2β\sin 2\betasin2β and of the ratio ΔMd/ΔMs\Delta M_d/\Delta M_sΔMd​/ΔMs​ its role in the CKM fits declined because of the large error in B^K\hat B_KB^K​. Also for this reason the size of CP violation in the KKK and BBB systems were commonly declared to be compatible with each other within the SM.

This situation changed in 2008 due to the improved value of B^K\hat B_KB^K​, the improved determinations of the elements of the CKM matrix and in particular due to the inclusion of additional corrections to ϵK\epsilon_KϵK​~256 that were neglected in the past, enhancing the role of this CP-violating parameter in the search for NP.

Indeed it has been recently stressed 256 that the SM prediction for ϵK\epsilon_KϵK​ implied by the measured value of sin⁡2β\sin2\betasin2β may be too small to agree with experiment. The main reasons for this are on the one hand a decreased value of B^K=0.724±0.008±0.028\hat B_K=0.724\pm 0.008\pm 0.028B^K​=0.724±0.008±0.028~257 (see also 258), lower by 5--10\% with respect to the values used in UT fits until recently and on the other hand the decreased value of ϵK\epsilon_KϵK​ in the SM arising from a multiplicative factor, estimated as κϵ=0.92±0.02\kappa_\epsilon=0.92\pm 0.02κϵ​=0.92±0.02~256259. Earlier discussions of such corrections can be found in 260261262.

Given that ϵK∝B^Kκϵ\epsilon_K \propto\hat B_K \kappa_\epsilonϵK​∝B^K​κϵ​, the total suppression of ϵK\epsilon_KϵK​ compared to the commonly used formulae is typically of order 15−20%15-20\%15−20% and using ( ?), ( ?) and (Eq. 6) one finds now~259

∣ϵK∣SM=(1.78±0.25)×10−3, |\epsilon_K|^SM = (1.78 \pm 0.25) \times 10^{-3} ,∣ϵK​∣SM=(1.78±0.25)×10−3,

to be compared to the experimental measurement 263

∣ϵK∣exp=(2.229±0.010)×10−3. |\epsilon_K|^exp = (2.229 \pm 0.010) \times 10^{-3} .∣ϵK​∣exp=(2.229±0.010)×10−3.

The 15\% error in ( ?) arises from the three main sources of uncertainty that are still B^K\hat B_KB^K​, ∣Vcb∣4|V_{cb}|^4∣Vcb​∣4 and Rt2R_t^2Rt2​. However, it should be stressed that B^K\hat B_KB^K​ known by now with 4%4\%4% accuracy is not the main uncertainty which now is dominantly due to ∣Vcb∣\vcb∣Vcb​∣ and in the ballpark of 10%10\%10%.

As seen in ( ?) the agreement between the SM and (Eq. 10) improves for higher values of B^K\hat B_KB^K​, RtR_tRt​ or ∣Vcb∣|V_{cb}|∣Vcb​∣ and also the correlation between ϵK\epsilon_KϵK​ and sin⁡2β\sin 2 \betasin2β within the SM is highly sensitive to these parameters. Consequently improved determinations of all these parameters are very desirable in order to find out whether NP is at work in SψKSS_{\psi K_S}SψKS​​ or in ϵK\epsilon_KϵK​ or both. Some ideas can be found in~264256259265.

The tension in question can be also seen in the most recent fit of the UTfit collaboration shown in Fig.~Fig. 2, which now also includes the κε\kappa_{\varepsilon}κε​ correction. In order to see this more transparently let us have now a look at the Rb−γR_b-\gammaRb​−γ plane in Fig.~Fig. 4 taken from 55, where details on input parameters can be found. There, in the upper left plot the blue (green) region corresponds to the 1σ\sigmaσ allowed range for sin⁡2β\sin2\betasin2β (RtR_tRt​) as calculated by means of (Eq. 6). The red region corresponds to ∣ϵK∣|\epsilon_K|∣ϵK​∣ as obtained by equating ( ?) with (Eq. 10). Finally the solid black line corresponds to α=90∘\alpha=90^\circα=90∘ that is close to the value favoured by UT fits and the determination from B→ρρB\to\rho\rhoB→ρρ 247.

It is evident that there is a tension between various regions as there are three different values of (Rb,γ)(R_b, \gamma)(Rb​,γ), dependending on which two constraints are simultaneously applied. The four immediate solutions to this tension are as follows:

1. There is a positive NP effect in ϵK\epsilon_KϵK​ while sin⁡2β\sin 2\betasin2β and ΔMd/ΔMs\Delta M_d/\Delta M_sΔMd​/ΔMs​ are SM-like 256, as shown by the upper right plot of Fig.~Fig. 4. The required effect in ϵK\epsilon_KϵK​ could be for instance achieved within models with CMFV by a positive shift in the function S0(xt)S_0(x_t)S0​(xt​)~259 which, while not modifying $(\sin2\beta)_{\psi K_S}andandand\Delta M_d / \Delta M_s$, would require the preferred values of B^Bd,sFBd,s\sqrt{\hat B_{B_{d,s}}} F_{B_{d,s}}B^Bd,s​​​FBd,s​​ to be by ≃10%\simeq 10\%≃10% lower than the present central values in order to fit ΔMd\Delta M_dΔMd​ and ΔMs\Delta M_sΔMs​ separately. Alternatively, new non-minimal sources of flavour violation relevant only for the KKK system could solve the problem. Note that this solution corresponds to γ≃66∘\gamma \simeq 66^\circγ≃66∘, Rb≃0.36R_b \simeq 0.36Rb​≃0.36 and α≃93∘\alpha \simeq 93^\circα≃93∘ in accordance with the usual UT analysis. 2. ϵK\epsilon_KϵK​ and ΔMd/ΔMs\Delta M_d/\Delta M_sΔMd​/ΔMs​ are NP free while $S_{\psi K_S}isaffectedbyaNPphaseis affected by a NP phaseisaffectedbyaNPphase\phi_{B_d}$ in BdB_dBd​ mixing of approximately −7∘-7^\circ−7∘ as indicated in (Eq. 7) and shown by the lower left plot of Fig.~Fig. 4. The predicted value for sin⁡2β\sin2\betasin2β is now shifted to sin⁡2β≈0.85\sin 2\beta\approx 0.85sin2β≈0.85 264256265259. This value is significantly larger than the measured SψKSS_{\psi K_S}SψKS​​ which allows to fit the experimental value of ϵK\epsilon_KϵK​. Note that this solution is characterized by a large value of Rb≃0.47R_b \simeq 0.47Rb​≃0.47, that is significantly larger than its exclusive determinations but still compatible with the inclusive determinations. The angles γ≃66∘\gamma \simeq 66^\circγ≃66∘ and α≃87∘\alpha \simeq 87^\circα≃87∘ agree with the usual UT analysis. 3. ϵK\epsilon_KϵK​ and SψKSS_{\psi K_S}SψKS​​ are NP free while the determination of RtR_tRt​ through ΔMd/ΔMs\Delta M_d/\Delta M_sΔMd​/ΔMs​ is affected by NP as indicated in (Eq. 7) and shown by the lower right plot of Fig.~Fig. 4. In that scenario one finds ΔMdSM/ΔMsSM\Delta M_d^SM / \Delta M_s^SMΔMdS​M/ΔMsS​M to be much higher than the actual measurement. In order to agree exactly with the experimental central value, one needs a NP contribution to ΔMd/ΔMs\Delta M_d / \Delta M_sΔMd​/ΔMs​ at the level of −22%-22\%−22%. Non-universal contributions suppressing ΔMd\Delta M_dΔMd​ (CBd<1C_{B_d} \lt {1}CBd​​<1) and/or enhancing ΔMs\Delta M_sΔMs​ (CBs>1C_{B_s} \gt {1}CBs​​>1) could be responsible for this shift as is evident from (Eq. 7). The increased value of RtR_tRt​ that compensates the negative effect of NP in ΔMd/ΔMs\Delta M_d/\Delta M_sΔMd​/ΔMs​ allows to fit the experimental value of ϵK\epsilon_KϵK​.

This solution is characterized by a large value of γ≃84∘\gamma\simeq 84^\circγ≃84∘ and α\alphaα much below 90∘90^\circ90∘. The latter fact could become problematic for this solution when the determination of α\alphaα further improves.

4. The value of ∣Vcb∣\vcb∣Vcb​∣ is significantly increased to roughly 43.5⋅10−343.5\cdot 10^{-3}43.5⋅10−3, which seems rather unlikely.

The first three NP scenarios characterized by black points in Fig.~Fig. 4 will be clearly distinguished from each other once the values of γ\gammaγ and RbR_bRb​ from tree level decays will be precisely known. Moreover, if future measurements of (Rb,γ)(R_b,\gamma)(Rb​,γ) will select a point in the Rb−γR_b - \gammaRb​−γ plane that differs from the black points in Fig.~Fig. 4, it is likely that NP will simultaneously enter ϵK\epsilon_KϵK​, SψKSS_{\psi K_S}SψKS​​ and ΔMd/ΔMs\Delta M_d / \Delta M_sΔMd​/ΔMs​. It will be interesting to monitor future progress in the Rb−γR_b-\gammaRb​−γ plane.

Finally, let us mention that the tensions discussed above could be in principle somewhat reduced through penguin contributions to B→ψKSB\to\psi K_SB→ψKS​ 266267. However a different view has been expressed in 268, where such effects have been found to be negligible.

Rare Decays \mathbf{\kpn and KL→π0ννˉ\mathbf{\klpn}KL​→π0ννˉ}

Let us next discuss in more detail two most popular decays among rare KKK decays: K+→π+ννˉ\kpnK+→π+ννˉ and KL→π0ννˉ\klpnKL​→π0ννˉ. These decays are theoretically very clean and very sensitive to NP contributions in ZZZ penguin diagrams. It is then not surprising that theorists invested over 25 years to improve the SM prediction and to analyze these decays in many extensions of the SM. The most recent predictions that include NNLO QCD corrections and electroweak corrections read 3536 \be Br(\kpn)_SM=(8.5\pm0.7)\cdot 10^{-11}, \ee

\be Br(\klpn)_SM=(2.8\pm0.6)\cdot 10^{-11}, \ee where the errors are dominated by parametrical uncertainties, in particular by the CKM parameters. In the past a sizable uncertainty in Br(K+→π+ννˉ)Br(\kpn)Br(K+→π+ννˉ) was due to the charm quark mass. But presently mcm_cmc​ is known to be mc(mc)=1.279±0.013 GeVm_c(m_c)=1.279\pm0.013\gevmc​(mc​)=1.279±0.013GeV 127 and this uncertainty is basically eliminated. Also very significant progress has been made in estimating non-perturbative contributions to the charm component 168 and in the determination of the relevant hadronic matrix elements from tree level leading KKK decays 169. Reviews of these two decays can be found in 269270271272273.

On the experimental side seven events of K+→π+ννˉ\kpnK+→π+ννˉ decay have been observed by E787 and E949 at Brookhaven resulting in 274 \be Br(\kpn)=(17.3^{+11.5}_{-10.5})\cdot 10^{-11}\,. \ee The experimental upper bound on Br(KL→π0ννˉ)Br(\klpn)Br(KL​→π0ννˉ) is still by more than two orders of magnitude above the SM value in ( ?) but the present upper bound from E391a at KEK 275 of Br(KL→π0ννˉ)≤6.7⋅10−8Br(\klpn)\le 6.7\cdot 10^{-8}Br(KL​→π0ννˉ)≤6.7⋅10−8 should be significantly improved in the coming decade. Experimental prospects for both decays have been already mentioned in connection with Goal 10 on our list.

Once measured, these decays will provide a very clean determination of the angle β\betaβ in the UT as some parametric uncertainties, in particular the value of ∣Vcb∣\vcb∣Vcb​∣, cancel out in this determination. This implies one of the golden relation of MFV 249276 that connects KKK and BBB physics, \be (\sin2\beta)_{S_{\psi K_S}} = (\sin2\beta)_{\klpn} , \ee which can be strongly violated in models with new flavour and CP-violating interactions, such as the LHT model 27773 and the RSc model analyzed in 83.

While the test of the relation ( ?) in future experiments will tell us whether some NP disturbs this MFV correlation, in order to identify which NP is at work we have to do much more and consider other decays and observables.

To this end let us first list the maximal enhancements of these two branching ratios in a number of NP scenarios. These are given in the second and third column of Table~Table 1, where 100%100\%100% means an enhancement of the branching ratio by a factor of two. These enhancements in a given NP scenario are consistent with all existing data but could be significantly decreased through various correlations when new observables will be measured.

A striking hierarchy of enhancements is exhibited in this table: - In the GMSSM still very large enhancements are possible. More modest but still large enhancements are possible in the LHT model 27773 and in the RSc model 83. In the GMSSM and the LHT model the central experimental value of Br(K+→π+ννˉ)Br(\kpn)Br(K+→π+ννˉ) in ( ?) can be reproduced. In the RSc model values above 15×10−1115\times 10^{-11}15×10−11 are rather unlikely. - Enhancements of both branching ratios in CMFV and MFV scenarios are small, but as the theory is very clean, powerful experiments will be able to distinguish these NP scenarios on the basis of these decays one day. Yet, the confirmation of the central value for Br(K+→π+ννˉ)Br(\kpn)Br(K+→π+ννˉ) in ( ?) with a precision of 10%10\%10% would certainly tell us that non-MFV interactions are at work. - The branching ratios for both decays in supersymmetric flavour models considered in subsequent subsections are basically indistinguishable from the SM predictions for K→πννˉK\to\pi\nu\bar\nuK→πννˉ decays, but as we will see soon these models perform quite differently in the BsB_sBs​ system or more explicitly in b→sb\to sb→s transitions, both CP-conserving and CP-violating.

The VIP's of \mathbf{B_s Physics: Bs,d→μ+μ−\mathbf{B_{s,d}\to \mu^+\mu^-}Bs,d​→μ+μ− and Sψϕ\mathbf{S_{\psi\phi}}Sψϕ​}

We will move now to discuss Goals 6 and 4 in more detail. These goals are in my opinion the most important goals in quark flavour physics until the next EPS11 conference, to be joined later by K→πννˉK\to\pi\nu\bar\nuK→πννˉ decays so that EPS13 will indeed have them all. We will first discuss these two goals separately. Subsequently we will have a grand simultaneous look at SψϕS_{\psi\phi}Sψϕ​, Bs→μ+μ−B_s\to\mu^+\mu^-Bs​→μ+μ−, K+→π+ννˉK^+\to\pi^+\nu\bar\nuK+→π+ννˉ and KL→π0ννˉ\klpnKL​→π0ννˉ that we have already anticipated when constructing Table~Table 1.

\mathbf{Br(B_{s,d\to \mu^+\mu^-)}}

One of the main targets of flavour physics in the coming years will be the measurement of the branching ratio for the highly suppressed decay Bs→μ+μ−B_s\to\mu^+\mu^-Bs​→μ+μ−. Hopefully the even more suppressed decay Bd→μ+μ−B_d\to \mu^+\mu^-Bd​→μ+μ− will be discovered as well. These two decays are helicity suppressed in the SM and CMFV models. Their branching ratios are proportional to the squares of the corresponding weak decay constants that suffer still from sizable uncertainties as discussed in the context of Goal 2. However using simultaneously the SM expressions for the very well measured mass differences ΔMs,d\Delta M_{s,d}ΔMs,d​, this uncertainty can be eliminated 278 leaving the uncertainties in the hadronic parameters B^Bs\hat B_{B_s}B^Bs​​ and B^Bd\hat B_{B_d}B^Bd​​ as the only theoretical uncertainty in Br(Bs,d→μ+μ−)Br(B_{s,d}\to\mu^+\mu^-)Br(Bs,d​→μ+μ−). As seen in ( ?) these parameters are already known from lattice calculations 125 with precision of 10%10\%10% and enter the branching ratios linearly.

Explicitly we have in the SM 278 \be Br(B_{q}\to\mu^+\mu^-) =C\frac{\tau(B_{q})}{\hat B_{B_{q}}} \frac{Y^2(x_t)}{S(x_t)} \Delta M_{q}, \qquad (q=s,d) \ee with \be C={6\pi}\frac{\eta_Y^2}{\eta_B} \left(\frac{\alpha}{4\pi\sin^2\theta_{W}}\right)^2\frac{m_\mu^2}{\mw^2} =4.39\cdot 10^{-10}. \ee S(xt)=2.32±0.07S(x_t)=2.32\pm 0.07S(xt​)=2.32±0.07 and Y(xt)=0.94±0.03Y(x_t)=0.94\pm0.03Y(xt​)=0.94±0.03 are the relevant top mass dependent one-loop functions. More generally we have in CMFV models \be \frac{Br(B_{q}\to\mu\bar\mu)}{\Delta M_{q}} =4.4 \cdot 10^{-10} \frac{\tau(B_{q})}{\hat B_{q}} F(v), \qquad F(v)=\frac{Y^2(v)}{S(v)}, \ee with Y(v)Y(v)Y(v) and S(v)S(v)S(v) replacing Y(xt)Y(x_t)Y(xt​) and S(xt)S(x_t)S(xt​) in a given CMFV model. Using these expressions one finds in the SM the rather precise predictions \be Br(B_s\to \mu^+\mu^-)= (3.6\pm0.4)\cdot 10^{-9}, \qquad Br(B_d\to \mu^+\mu^-)= (1.1\pm0.1)\cdot 10^{-10}. \ee

These predictions should be compared to the 95%95\%95% C.L. upper limits from CDF 279 and D0 280 (in parentheses) \be Br(B_s\to \mu^+\mu^-)\le 3.3 (5.3)\cdot 10^{-8}, \qquad Br(B_d\to \mu^+\mu^-)\le 1 \cdot 10^{-8}. \ee The numbers given above are updates presented at this conference. More information is given by Giovanni Punzi. It is clear from ( ?) and ( ?) that a lot of room is still left for NP contributions.

Now, irrespectively of large uncertainties in the separate SM predictions for Bs,d→μ+μ−B_{s,d}\to\mu^+\mu^-Bs,d​→μ+μ− and ΔMs,d\Delta M_{s,d}ΔMs,d​, there exists a rather precise relation between these observables that can be considered as one of the theoretically cleanest predictions of CMFV. This golden relation reads 278 \be \frac{Br(B_s\to\mu^+\mu^-)}{Br(B_d\to\mu^+\mu^-)}= \frac{\hat B_{B_d}}{\hat B_{B_s}} \frac{\tau(B_s)}{\tau(B_d)} \frac{\Delta M_s}{\Delta M_d}\,r\,, \ee with r=1r=1r=1 in CMFV models but generally different from unity. For instance in the LHT model one finds 0.3≤r≤1.60.3\le r\le 1.60.3≤r≤1.6 27773, while in the RSc model 0.6≤r≤1.30.6\le r \le 1.30.6≤r≤1.3 83. Also in supersymmetric models discussed below rrr can deviate strongly from unity.

It should be stressed that the ratio B^Bd/B^Bs=1.00±0.03\hat B_{B_d}/\hat B_{B_s}=1.00\pm 0.03B^Bd​​/B^Bs​​=1.00±0.03 125 constitutes the only theoretical uncertainty in ( ?). The remaining quantities entering ( ?) can be obtained directly from experimental data. The right hand side is already known rather precisely: 32.5±1.732.5\pm 1.732.5±1.7, but it will still take some time before the left hand side will be known with comparable precision unless NP enhances both branching ratios by an order of magnitude. In the latter case one will very likely find r≠1r\not=1r=1 as within CMFV models such large enhancements of Br(Bs,d→μ+μ−)Br(B_{s,d}\to\mu^+\mu^-)Br(Bs,d​→μ+μ−) are not possible.

Large contributions to the branching ratios in question can come from neutral scalar exchanges (Higgs penguins) 281282 in which case new scalar operators are generated and the helicity suppression is lifted. Thus large enhancements of $B_{s,d}\to \mu^+\mu^-$ are only possible in the models placed in the entries (1,2) and (2,2) of the flavour matrix in Fig.~Fig. 1. The prime example here is the MSSM at large tan⁡β\tan\betatanβ, in which still in 2002 Br(Bs→μ+μ−)Br(B_s\to\mu^+\mu^-)Br(Bs​→μ+μ−) could be as large as 10−610^{-6}10−6. The impressive progress by CDF and D0 collaborations, leading to a decrease of the corresponding upper bound by two orders of magnitude totally excluded this possibility but there is still hope that a clear signal of NP at the level of O(10−8)\ord(10^{-8})O(10−8) will be seen in these decays. We will discuss a number of SUSY predictions below, where such enhancements are still possible.

In the MSSM with MFV and large tan⁡β\tan\betatanβ there is a strong correlation between Br(Bs,d→μ+μ−)Br(B_{s,d}\to \mu^+\mu^-)Br(Bs,d​→μ+μ−) and ΔMs\Delta M_sΔMs​ 283284285286287 implying that an enhancement of these branching ratios with respect to the SM is correlated with a suppression of ΔMs\Delta M_sΔMs​ below the SM value. In fact the MSSM with MFV was basically the only model that ``predicted'' the suppression of ΔMs\Delta M_sΔMs​ below the SM prediction as seemed to be the case just after the discovery of the Bs0−Bˉs0B^0_s-\bar B^0_sBs0​−Bˉs0​ mixing. Meanwhile the lattice values for weak decay constants changed and there is no suppression relativ to (ΔMs)SM(\Delta M_s)_SM(ΔMs​)S​M seen within theoretical uncertainties in the data. With the decrease of the experimental upper bound on Br(Bs,d→μ+μ−)Br(B_{s,d}\to \mu^+\mu^-)Br(Bs,d​→μ+μ−) also in the MSSM with MFV the predicted suppression of ΔMs\Delta M_sΔMs​ amounts to at most 10%10\%10% and it will require a considerable reduction of the lattice uncertainties in the evaluation of (ΔMs)SM(\Delta M_s)_SM(ΔMs​)S​M before the correlation in question can be verified or falsified by experiment. As we will see soon, in the MSSM with non-MFV interactions the correlation discussed here is absent 55. Other analyses of this issue can be found in 28828965 and a review on Higgs penguins can be found in 290. Also in models with hybrid gauge-gravity mediation the MFV-like correlattion in question can be strongly modified 291.

Looking at Br(Bs,d→μ+μ−)Br(B_{s,d}\to\mu^+\mu^-)Br(Bs,d​→μ+μ−) in CMFV, MFV, LHT, RSc, GMSSM and the specific supersymmetric flavour models AC, RVV2, AKM, δ\deltaδLL and FBMSSM we identify a striking hierarchy of possible enhancements that is, as seen in table~Table 1, opposite to the one found in the case of K→πννˉK\to\pi\nu\bar\nuK→πννˉ decays. An exception to this pattern is GMSSM: - In the GMSSM, SUSY with MFV and all SUSY flavour models Br(Bs,d→μ+μ−)Br(B_{s,d}\to\mu^+\mu^-)Br(Bs,d​→μ+μ−) can still reach the present experimental bounds because of the presence of Higgs penguins that become very important at large tan⁡β\tan\betatanβ: a (tan⁡β)6(\tan\beta)^6(tanβ)6 enhancement of the branching ratios is present in this case. - In CMFV, the LHT and the RSc only enhancements of 20%20\%20%, 30%30\%30% and 10%10\%10% are possible 2777383 as Higgs penguins are irrelevant here and the Z-penguins in spite of non-MFV interactions in the case of the LHT and the RSc do not lift the helicity suppression. Moreover the custodial protection of left-handed Z couplings in the RSc allows only right-handed Z couplings to be relevant and these cannot do much in this case 83.

Recently a closer look at Br(Bs,d→μ+μ−)Br(B_{s,d}\to\mu^+\mu^-)Br(Bs,d​→μ+μ−) has been made in the context of specific SUSY flavour models such as AC, RVV2, AKM, δ\deltaδLL showing that the measurement of both branching ratios Br(Bs,d→μ+μ−)Br(B_{s,d}\to \mu^+\mu^-)Br(Bs,d​→μ+μ−) can not only test the golden MFV relation in ( ?) but also give some insight in different SUSY flavour models. We find 55: - The ratio Br(Bd→μ+μ−)/Br(Bs→μ+μ−)Br(B_d\to\mu^+\mu^-)/Br(B_s\to\mu^+\mu^-)Br(Bd​→μ+μ−)/Br(Bs​→μ+μ−) in the AC and RVV2 models is dominantly below its CMFV prediction in ( ?) and can be much smaller than the latter. In the AKM model this ratio stays much closer to the MFV value of roughly 1/331/331/33 27853 and can be smaller or larger than this value with equal probability. Still, values of Br(Bd→μ+μ−)Br(B_d\to\mu^+\mu^-)Br(Bd​→μ+μ−) as high as 1×10−91\times 10^{-9}1×10−9 are possible in all these models as Br(Bs→μ+μ−)Br(B_s\to\mu^+\mu^-)Br(Bs​→μ+μ−) can be strongly enhanced. We show this in the case of the RVV2 model in the left plot of Fig.~Fig. 5. - Interestingly, in the δ\deltaδLL-models, the ratio Br(Bd→μ+μ−)/Br(Bs→μ+μ−)Br(B_d\to\mu^+\mu^-)/Br(B_s\to\mu^+\mu^-)Br(Bd​→μ+μ−)/Br(Bs​→μ+μ−) can not only deviate significantly from its CMFV value, but in contrast to the models with right-handed currents considered by us can also be much larger that the MFV value. Consequently, Br(Bd→μ+μ−)Br(B_d\to\mu^+\mu^-)Br(Bd​→μ+μ−) as high as (1−2)×10−9(1-2)\times 10^{-9}(1−2)×10−9 is still possible while being consistent with the bounds on all other observables, in particular the one on Br(Bs→μ+μ−)Br(B_s\to\mu^+\mu^-)Br(Bs​→μ+μ−). We show this in the right plot of Fig.~Fig. 5.

The \mathbf{S_{\psi\phi} Asymmetry}

The tiny complex phase of the element VtsV_{ts}Vts​ in the CKM matrix precludes any sizable CP violating effects in the decays of the BsB_sBs​ mesons within the SM and models with MFV. In particular the very clean mixing induced asymmetry SψϕS_{\psi\phi}Sψϕ​ is predicted to be \be (S_{\psi\phi})_SM=\sin(2|\beta_s|)\approx 0.04, \ee with −βs-\beta_s−βs​ being the phase of VtsV_{ts}Vts​. As pointed out in 292 some hadronic uncertainties not discussed in the past could still be non-negligible so that values of SψϕS_{\psi\phi}Sψϕ​ as high as 0.10.10.1 could not be immidiately considered as signals of NP. However the same paper proposes various strategies to overcome these difficulties through additional measurements of different decay channels that will be available in the coming years.

In the presence of new physics ( ?) is modified as follows 19, \be S_{\psi\phi}=\sin(2|\beta_s|-2\phi_{B_s}), \ee where ϕBs\phi_{B_s}ϕBs​​ is a new phase in Bs0−Bˉs0B^0_s-\bar B^0_sBs0​−Bˉs0​ mixing as defined in (Eq. 8).

Already in 2006 Lenz and Nierste 293, analyzing D0 and CDF data pointed out some hints for a large phase ϕBs\phi_{B_s}ϕBs​​. In 2008 new hints appeared, emphasized in particular by the UTfit collaboration 294. The most recent messages from CDF and D0 295 imply a 2.7σ2.7\sigma2.7σ deviation from the SM prediction and we have to wait for higher statistics in order to conclude that NP is at work here 296. Explicitly CDF and D0 find 133 \be S_{\psi\phi}\approx 0.81^{+0.12}_{-0.32}. \ee As the central value of the measured SψϕS_{\psi\phi}Sψϕ​ is around 0.80.80.8, that is one order of magnitude larger than the SM value, the confirmation of this high value in the future would be a spectacular confirmation of non-MFV interactions at work. As demonstrated recently such large values can easily be found in the RSc model 82 and the same comment applies to the GMSSM. The most likely values for SψϕS_{\psi\phi}Sψϕ​ in the LHT do not exceed 0.3 73 and finding this asymmetry as high as 0.4 would be in favour of the RSc and the GMSSM. Similarly the supersymmetric flavour models with significant right-handed currents (AC, RVV2, AKM) provide sizable enhancements. Here the double Higgs penguin contributing to M12sM_{12}^sM12s​ is at work. The following hierarchy in maximal values is found (see Table~Table 1)

(Sψϕ)LHTmax≈(Sψϕ)AKMmax<(Sψϕ)RVV2max<(Sψϕ)RScmax≈(Sψϕ)ACmax. (S_{\psi\phi})_LHT^max\approx (S_{\psi\phi})_AKM^max \lt (S_{\psi\phi})_RVV2^max \lt (S_{\psi\phi})_RSc^max \approx (S_{\psi\phi})_AC^max.(Sψϕ​)L​HTmax≈(Sψϕ​)A​KMmax<(Sψϕ​)R​VV2max<(Sψϕ​)R​Scmax≈(Sψϕ​)A​Cmax.

On the other hand SψϕS_{\psi\phi}Sψϕ​ in the flavour models with only left-handed currents and in the FBMSSM is SM-like.

Clearly a sizable SψϕS_{\psi\phi}Sψϕ​ is not the only manifestation of CP violation in the BsB_sBs​ system but presently it is the most prominent one as it can be measured accurately at LHCb, it is theoretically rather clean and the leftover uncertainties could be further decreased using the strategies in 292. In Fig.~Fig. 6 we show the correlation between the semi-leptonic asymmetry ASLsA_{SL}^sASLs​ and SψϕS_{\psi\phi}Sψϕ​ in the RSc and AC models. This correlation is basically model independent 297 and shows that in any model in which SψϕS_{\psi\phi}Sψϕ​ deviates significantly from its SM value, also ASLsA_{SL}^sASLs​ will be very much enhanced. Other implications of a large SψϕS_{\psi\phi}Sψϕ​ in the context of concrete models will be discussed below.

Correlations between \mathbf{\kpn, KL→π0ννˉ\mathbf{\klpn}KL​→π0ννˉ, Bs→μ+μ−\mathbf{B_s\to\mu^+\mu^-}Bs​→μ+μ− and Sψϕ\mathbf{S_{\psi\phi}}Sψϕ​}

In Table~Table 1 we collect the largest possible enhancements for the corresponding branching ratios and SψϕS_{\psi\phi}Sψϕ​ in various extensions of the SM discussed in this talk. It is evident that if we knew already the values of these four observables that are given to us by nature, we could already make a clear distinction between certain scenarios provided the deviations from the SM would be large.

This table does not take into account possible correlations between these four observables and it is important to list some of them: - Simultaneous enhancements of SψϕS_{\psi\phi}Sψϕ​ and of Br(K→πννˉ)Br(K\to\pi\nu\bar\nu)Br(K→πννˉ) in the LHT and the RSc scenario are rather unlikely 7383. This feature is more pronounced in the RSc model. We show this correlation in Fig.~Fig. 7. - On the contrary the desire to explain the SψϕS_{\psi\phi}Sψϕ​ anomaly within the supersymmetric flavour models with right-handed currents implies, in the case of the AC and AKM models, values of Br(Bs→μ+μ−)Br(B_s\to\mu^+\mu^-)Br(Bs​→μ+μ−) as high as several 10−810^{-8}10−8. This are very exciting news for the CDF, D0 and LHCb experiments! In the RVV2 model such values are also possible but not necessarily implied by the large value of SψϕS_{\psi\phi}Sψϕ​. We show one example of this spectacular correlation for the case of the AC model in the left plot of Fig.~Fig. 8. - While in the case of the LHT model some definite correlations between Br(KL→π0ννˉ)Br(\klpn)Br(KL​→π0ννˉ) and Br(K+→π+ννˉ)Br(\kpn)Br(K+→π+ννˉ) can be seen 73, no such correlations are found in the case of the RSc model 83, although in both models the enhancements of the two branching ratios can take place simultaneously. We show this feature in Fig.~Fig. 9. Some insights in this different behaviour have been recently provided in 298. More correlations in all these models can be found in the papers quoted above but I think the first two on the list above are the most interesting in the quark flavour sector. Certainly a precise measurement of SψϕS_{\psi\phi}Sψϕ​, in particular if SψϕS_{\psi\phi}Sψϕ​ will be found to be much larger than its SM value, will have an important impact on the models discussed here.

The Correlation between the \mathbf{S_{\psi\phi} and SϕKS\mathbf{S_{\phi K_S}}SϕKS​​ Anomalies}

Before leaving quark flavour physics let me return for a moment to the SϕKSS_{\phi K_S}SϕKS​​ anomaly in ( ?) and discuss it together with the SψϕS_{\psi\phi}Sψϕ​ anomaly. These anomalies can be explained simultaneously in the GMSSM but the situation is more interesting in supersymmetric flavour (SF) models.

Indeed the SUSY flavour models with right-handed currents (AC, RVV2, AKM) and those with exclusively left-handed currents (δLL\delta LLδLL) can be globally distinguished by the values of the CP-asymmetries SψϕS_{\psi\phi}Sψϕ​ and SϕKSS_{\phi K_S}SϕKS​​ with the following important result: none of the models considered by us in 55 can simultaneously explain the SψϕS_{\psi\phi}Sψϕ​ and SϕKSS_{\phi K_S}SϕKS​​ anomalies observed in the data. In the models with right-handed currents, SψϕS_{\psi\phi}Sψϕ​ can naturally be much larger than its SM value, while SϕKSS_{\phi K_S}SϕKS​​ remains either SM-like or its correlation with SψϕS_{\psi\phi}Sψϕ​ is inconsistent with the data. On the contrary, in the models with left-handed currents only, SψϕS_{\psi\phi}Sψϕ​ remains SM-like, while the SϕKSS_{\phi K_S}SϕKS​​ anomaly can easily be solved. Thus already precise measurements of SψϕS_{\psi\phi}Sψϕ​ and SϕKSS_{\phi K_S}SϕKS​​ in the near future will select one of these two classes of models, if any.

We will still have something to say about the correlation of these two anomalies with observables in the lepton sector in the context of the SF models in question.

Lepton Flavour Violation, EDM's and \mathbf{(g-2)_\mu}

Let us finally discuss some additional aspects of Goals 16-18 on our list for the next decade. In 55 we have also performed a very detailed analysis of LFV, EDM's and of (g−2)μ(g-2)_\mu(g−2)μ​ in the supersymmetric flavour models AC, RVV2, AKM and δ\deltaδLL. Particular emphasis has been put on correlations between these observables in each of these models and their correlation with flavour observables in the quark sector discussed exclusively in this section until now. Let us just list the most striking results of this study keeping in mind that the models with right-handed currents (AC, RVV2, AKM) have the potential to explain the SψϕS_{\psi\phi}Sψϕ​ anomaly while the δ\deltaδLL model could explain the SϕKSS_{\phi K_S}SϕKS​​ anomaly. Here we go.

1. The desire to explain the SψϕS_{\psi\phi}Sψϕ​ anomaly within the models with right-handed currents automatically implies a solution to the (g−2)μ(g-2)_\mu(g−2)μ​ anomaly. We illustrate this for the AC model in the right plot of Fig.~Fig. 8. 2. In the RVV2 and the AKM models, a large value of SψϕS_{\psi\phi}Sψϕ​ combined with the desire to explain the (g−2)μ(g-2)_\mu(g−2)μ​ anomaly implies Br(μ→eγ)Br(\mu\to e\gamma)Br(μ→eγ) in the reach of the MEG experiment. In the case of the RVV2 model, de≥10−29d_e\ge 10^{-29}de​≥10−29 e cm. is predicted, while in the AKM model it is typically smaller. Moreover, in the case of the RVV2 model, Br(τ→μγ)≥10−9Br(\tau\to\mu\gamma)\ge 10^{-9}Br(τ→μγ)≥10−9 is then in the reach of Super-B machines, while this is not the case in the AKM model. Some of these results are illustrated in Fig.~Fig. 10. 3. The hadronic EDM's represent very sensitive probes of SUSY flavour models with right-handed currents. In the AC model, large values for the neutron EDM might be easily generated by both the up- and strange-quark (C)EDM. In the former case, visible CP-violating effects in D0−Dˉ0D^0-\bar D^0D0−Dˉ0 mixing are also expected while in the latter case large CP-violating effects in the BsB_sBs​ system are unavoidable. The RVV2 and AKM models predict values for the down-quark (C)EDM and, hence for the neutron EDM, above the ≈10−28e\approx 10^{-28}e≈10−28e cm. level if a large SψϕS_{\psi\phi}Sψϕ​ is generated. All the above models predict a large strange-quark (C)EDM, hence, a reliable knowledge of its contribution to the hadronic EDM's by means of lattice QCD techniques would be of the utmost importance to probe or to falsify flavour models embedded in a SUSY framework. 4. In the supersymmetric models with exclusively left-handed currents (δ\deltaδLL), the desire to explain the SϕKSS_{\phi K_S}SϕKS​​ anomaly implies automatically a solution to the (g−2)μ(g-2)_\mu(g−2)μ​ anomaly and the direct CP asymmetry in b→sγb\to s\gammab→sγ much larger than its SM value. We illustrate this in Fig.~Fig. 11. Similar results are found in the FBMSSM 50. This is in contrast to the models with right-handed currents where the ACPbsγA_CP^{bs\gamma}AC​Pbsγ asymmetry remains SM-like.

Testing GUT Models with Rare B Decays

Next we would like to stress the power of the complex of rare BBB decays B→XsγB\to X_s\gammaB→Xs​γ, B→Xsl+l−B\to X_sl^+l^-B→Xs​l+l−, Bs,d→μ+μ−B_{s,d}\to\mu^+\mu^-Bs,d​→μ+μ− and B+→τ+ντB^+\to \tau^+\nu_\tauB+→τ+ντ​ in testing NP models. Many analyses of this type can be found in the literature. Here I would like to mention only the analysis of a very interesting SO(10)SO(10)SO(10)-GUT model of Dermisek and Raby 299 which gives a successful description of quark and lepton masses, of the PMNS matrix and of all elements of the CKM matrix except possibly for ∣Vub∣|V_{ub}|∣Vub​∣ that is found to be 3.2⋅10−33.2\cdot 10^{-3}3.2⋅10−3, definitely a bit too low. Yet as shown in 300, this model fails to describe simultaneously the data on the rare decays in question with supersymmetric particles in the reach of the LHC. This is mainly due to tan⁡β=50\tan\beta=50tanβ=50 required in this model. It can be shown that this is a problem of most GUTs with Yukawa unification 301. Possible solutions to this problem have been suggested in that paper. This discussion demonstrates that flavour physics can have a significant impact not only on physics at the LHC scales but also indirectly for much shorter scales connected with GUT's.

A DNA-Flavour Test of New Physics Models

We have seen above that the patterns of flavour violation found in various extensions of the SM differed from model to model, thereby allowing in the future to find out which of the models discussed by us, if any, can survive the future measurements. Undoubtedly, the correlations between various observables that are often characteristic for a given model will be of the utmost importance in these tests.

In Table~Table 2, taken from 55, a summary of the potential size of deviations from the SM results allowed for a large number of observables, considered in that paper and here, has been presented, taking into account all existing constraints from other observables. This table can be considered as the collection of the DNA's for various models. These DNA's will be modified as new experimental data will be availabe and in certain cases we will be able to declare certain models to be disfavoured or even ruled out. It should be emphasized that in constructing the table we did not take into account possible correlations among the observables listed there. We have seen that in some models it is not possible to obtain large effects simultaneously for certain pairs or sets of observables and consequently future measurements of a few observables considered in that table will have an impact on the patterns shown there. It will be interesting to monitor the changes in this table when future experiments will provide new results.

5. Final Messages and Five Big Questions

In our search for a more fundamental theory we need to improve our understanding of flavour physics. The study of flavour physics in conjuction with direct collider searches for new physics, with electroweak precision tests and cosmological investigations will without any doubt lead one day to a NSM. Whether this will happen in 2026 or only in 2046 it is not clear at present. Afterall, 35 years have passed since the completion of the present SM and no fully convincing candidate for the NSM exists in the literature. On the other hand in view of presently running and upcoming experiments, the next decade could be like 1970's in which practically every year a new important discovery has been made. Even if by 2026 a NSM may not exist yet, it is conceivable that we will be able to answer the following crucial questions by then: - Are there any fundamental scalars with masses Ms≤1 TeVM_s\le 1\tevMs​≤1TeV? - Are there any new fundamental fermions like vector-like fermions or the 4th generation of quarks and leptons? - Are there any new gauge bosons leading to new forces at very short distance scales and an extended gauge group? - What are the precise patterns of interactions between the gauge bosons, fermions and scalars with respect to flavour and CP Violation? - Can the answers to these four questions help us in understanding the BAU and other fundamental cosmological questions?

There are of course many other profound questions 302 related to grand unification, gravity and string theory and to other aspects of elementary particle physics and cosmology but from my point of view I would really be happy if in 2026 satisfactory answers to the five questions posed above were available. In this review written at the advent of the LHC era to which also several low energy precision machines belong, I wanted to emphasize that many observables in the quark and lepton flavour sectors have not been measured yet or are only poorly known and that flavour physics only now enters the precision era. Indeed, spectacular deviations from the SM and MFV expectations are still possible in flavour physics. The interplay of the expected deviations with direct searches at Tevatron, LHC and later at ILC will be most interesting.

In particular I emphasized the role of correlations between various observables in our search for the fundamental theory of flavour. These correlations and hopefully new discoveries, both in flavour physics and in direct searches for NP will pave the road to the New Standard Model.
